thread.title: Doi Dua heading home; Nodoguro could relocate
thread.title_full: Doi Dua heading home; Nodoguro could relocate | OregonLive.com

author: Michael Russell | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Doi Dua heading home; Nodoguro could relocate
text:
Two Portland restaurants, one a pop-up, the other a former pop-up, could both relocate around the end of the year.
No (more) Doi Dua
On Sunday, Doi Dua, the Vietnamese pop-up from Anna Vocaturo and partner Sarah Bui, announced plans to return to Washington D.C., where Vocaturo worked at chef Aaron Silverman's lauded Rose's Luxury . (That was Vocaturo on the cover of Bon Appetit's Best New Restaurants issue in 2014 ). "This past year has been so crazy," Vocaturo and Bui wrote on Facebook. "We've met some absolutely amazing people to share our food with here in Portland. That being said, we are excited to announce that Doi Dua is relocating to Washington, D.C."
The pop-up, which started at Hogan's Goat pizzeria this spring and has since popped up at Langbaan , will continue to book reservations for its Monday dinners through November.
Visit doidua-popup.com for more information.
Crab and citrus salad from Doi Dua. On Sunday, the Vietnamese pop up announced plans to relocate from Portland to Washington D.C. Samantha Bakall, The Oregonian Nodoguro moving?
Buried within the recent announcement that Pastaworks would leave Southeast Hawthorne Boulevard after three decades was this line about Nodoguro: "the acclaimed Japanese restaurant will remain in its current location at 3735 SE Hawthorne Blvd."
That's true, at least until January, says chef Ryan Roadhouse, whose restaurant received three stars for its Hardcore Omakase dinners earlier this year.
As recently as a few months ago, Roadhouse was under the impression that Pastaworks would stay in place, but "that chapter is pretty much over."
"There are a few options," Roadhouse said. "One of them is figuring out how to stay in the part of the space. ... We'll book out until the end of January and see what happens."
Option two is finding a new home.
There's a chance Nodoguro could stay on Southeast Hawthorne. Still, any enterprising landlords looking to poach one of Portland's hottest restaurants should consider dropping Roadhouse a line .
-- Michael Russell Follow @tdmrussell
